passages.text: Strategy European Daily Focus 司
Date 28 August 2025 Periodical
Thursday, 28th August 2025
BPER AND BPSO - Better together - deep dive into upside from the merger with BP Sondrio

Giovanni Razzoli: Target Price Changes: Banca Pop. Sondrio (BPSI.MI) - Hold, EUR10.80 to EUR11, BPER Banca S.p.A. (EMII.MI) - Buy, EUR8.40 to EUR12.10. Completion of the deal with BPSO strengthens our Buy on BPER - The offer for BP Sondrio (BPSO) reached \(81\%\) acceptance, with final integration planned by 1H26. We reiterate our Buy recommendation on BPER, upgrading the target price to EUR 12.1 p/s. We estimate room to exceed CET1 guidance at year- end \((>15\%)\) and the 2027 net profit target of \(>EUR2bn\) . The stronger franchise post- merger should justify a re- rating from the current 2026- 27E adj. P/E of 8.5- 7.8x. The deal accelerates BPER's growth, with the EPS CAGR increasing from \(2\%\) to \(6\%\) . Lombardy's dominance drives BPER's growth - BPER's acquisition of BPSO is strategically sound due to geographical and business complementarity, enhancing BPER's position in Lombardy. After the merger, BPER becomes the third- largest banking group domestically, becoming the largest player with a \(17\%\) market share in the wealthy region of Lombardy, overtaking Intesa SanPaolo's \(15\%\) .
Jonathan Jayarajan Research Analyst +44- 20- 754- 76037
GIVAUDAN (GIVN.S) - 2030 strategy & targets in- line, CEO succession announced

Virginie Boucher- Ferte: Tgt CHF3700. Last Close CHF3379, Hold. Givaudan's strategy for the next 5 years (2026- 2030) and new financial targets (4- 6% osg and FCF/sales \(>12\%\) ) are in the continuation of the current strategy and fully in- line with expectations. The much awaited leadership succession plans have been announced alongside the strategy announcement. Whilst the CEO retirement and proposed election as new chairman at the next AGM is fully in- line with expectations, his replacement will come as a surprise to investors as the new CEO is not an internal candidate and is relatively new to the financial community. Yet he's got a wealth of experience at EMCGs (o/w 20 years at Danone) and his experience may be additive to the culture which has delivered structural growth for the business. The stock trades at 25x 26EP/E and 19x 26EEV/EBITDA, a significant premium to peers, partly driven by management track record and stability so this appointment will no doubt be a clear area of focus for the markets.

IMPORTANT RESEARCH DISCLOSURES AND ANALYST CERTIFICATIONS LOCATED IN APPENDIX 1. Deutsche Bank does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. Thus, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.

Robert Grindle: We look forward to welcoming you to our 29th TMT Conference at our offices on the 3rd and 4th of September, 2025. The event will bring together investors and more than 60 corporates from all corners of Telecoms, Media and Technology. We hope that you have a very fruitful two days and we look forward to helping you with your investment decisions.

Gareth Davies / Nizla Naizer: We look forward to welcoming you to our 29th dbAccess European TMT conference at our London offices on the 3rd and 4th of September, 2025. The event will bring together investors and more than 60 corporates from all corners of Telecoms, Media and Technology. We hope that you have a very fruitful two days and we look forward to helping you with your investment decisions.

Thomas Rothaeusler: The German residential market remains in a stabilization phase with house prices continuing their soft upwards trend at unchanged momentum compared to the previous quarter and ongoing strong rental growth. Investment market activity remained muted with a further QoQ decline. Private mortgage volumes came down QoQ on higher mortgage rates but overall remained at much higher levels compared to last year's quarterly run rate. This is the key take from edition No. 8 of our quarterly residential market tracker, jointly produced by the Deutsche Bank Economics and Equity Research teams.
GENMAB (GMAB.CO) - Post-Q2: staying positive, PT to 1900.

Emmanuel Papadakis: Tgt DKK1750 to DKK1900. Last Close DKK1587, Buy. After providing brief takes on the Darzalex Q2 print (GMAB: Darzalex Q2'25 first take/JNJ x- reads (16/07/25)), we belatedly provide takes on and thoughts post GMAB's full Q2 results earlier this month. Those were a clear small positive, albeit however now a virtual sideshow to the investment case which has firmly shifted toward the outlook for the trio of potential replacement assets (Epkintly, Rina- S and acasunlimab) plus the early pipeline. The summary is that with GMAB profitable and set to generate its €15bn market cap in derisked, cumulative FCF + the c\\$3bn on the balance sheet by the end of the decade, we still think there is ample scope for the company to restore further equity value by enhancing confidence over Darzalex replacement prospects from Epkintly, Rina- S and the remaining pipeline (acasunlimab prospects remain TBD, in our view...). We remain Buy and lift our PT +9% to DKK 1900, based on an FY25 target P/E of 17x (and also slightly closer to our base case NPV), which is a slight discount to the SMID EU peer group at 18x but reflects strong near- term growth offset by longer- term challenges around Darzalex cliff.
ACCELLERON (ACLN.S) - Strong fundamentals but valuation stretched with growth priced in

John Kim: Tgt CHF39 to CHF62. Last Close CHF69.65, Hold. Historically, we've seen the investment case for Accelleron as driven by three key questions: 1) top- line growth, 2) margin expansion, and 3) potential upside from dividends/share buyback. Given updated guidance, we see top- line growth as the key part of the

story. Underlying fundamentals remain strong with positive market conditions in both Marine and Energy in- line with mgmt's guidance, incorporating tariff impacts in H2. We expect this growth to continue into FY25 but cannot find upside to the share price given current levels. Our new target price is CHF 2 as we roll forward our valuation and update our forecasts.
ACCELERON (ACLN.S) - H1 results: \(+5\%\) beat on op EBITA vs cons, slight cut to margin guide (tariffs)

John Kim: Tgt CHF39. Last Close CHF62, Hold. Group revenue grew \(+19\%\) yr/yr organic to US \(608m\) for H1 25 (pre- released). H1 operational EBITA of US \(155m\) was a \(+5\% / + 15\%\) beat against cons & DBe at a margin of \(25.5\% (+130bps\) above cons). H1 reported EPS came in at US \(1.17, a + 3\%\) beat vs cons and \(+10\%\) beat/ miss vs DBe. Within the divisions, the Low/ Medium speed division beat cons on rev and profit. The High speed division also beat cons on rev and profit. CF from operations was US \(106m\) in H1FY25 (vs US \(42m\) in H1FY24). Group FCF of US \(81m\) in H1FY25 (vs US \(30m\) in H1FY24). We expect a slight positive market reaction to the results despite a slight cut to the margin guide (now \(24 - 25\%\) due to tariffs, a - 100bp cut vs previous) with the underlying outlook strong in both Marine and Energy segments.

Thomas Rothaeusler: Tgt EUR3. Last Close EUR3.28, Hold. We view the reporting as a neutral event with confirmed FY25 guidance and unchanged rental growth momentum with Hotels and Residential leading the growth. Offices still remain weak with slow rent growth and high vacancy. Property values positive but with slower momentum vs second half last year. Set to capture internal growth with repositioning and office conversions. The company refers to external growth opportunities on the back of de- leveraging progress. AT confirmed FY25 guidance for FFO I at EUR280m- 310m (DBe EUR297m, BBG consensus EUR298m); EUR0.26- EUR0.28 (- 6.9% YoY at midpoint) on a per- share basis. 1H25 FFO I came in at EUR 150m (- 2% YoY). EPRA NTAs came in at EUR7.8 (+5% Ytd). Lfl rent growth at 3% (1Q25: 3%, FY24: 2.9%). Property values up 1.4% on Lfl basis (2H24: +1.9%, FY24: - 0.5%). EPRA LTV at 58% (FY24: 60%).

Alison Lygo: Tgt 100p. Last Close 97.36p, Hold. JD have reported Q2 trading with organic growth of \(+2.2\%\) and LFL of \(- 3\%\) in line with consensus expectations. Regionally, the US showed the best momentum, improving to \(- 2.3\%\) LFL (Q1- 5- 5%) which aligns with our expectation that the US is seeing a pull- forward of back- to- school demand. JD reference a good performance in newer footwear lines and strong performance in apparel, as well as much improved online supported by focussed marketing. However, the UK slowed to \(- 6\%\) (DBe \(- 2\%\) ) and Europe turned negative at \(- 1.1\%\) with the company referencing prior year support from Euro 2024.

Johannes Schaller: We look forward to welcoming you to our 29th TMT conference at our new offices on the 3rd and 4th of September, 2025. The event will bring together investors and more than 60 corporates from all corners of Telecoms,
Media and Technology. We hope that you have two very fruitful days and we look forward to helping you with your investment decisions.
DB MEDIA & ONLINE #WHAT'S APPENING - HTG/Update on Interhome, Trainline/Tracsis, DB TMT conf./3rd & 4th Sept

Silvia Cuneo: HomeToGo (Buy, last close: EUR1.825): Expects its already- announced acquisition of Interhome would complete latest by the 29th of August following the approval of the parallel Hotelplan transaction by Swiss authorities; positive. As a reminder, with the acquisition of Interhome, the second- largest vacation rental management company in Europe, HomeToGo becomes the leading player in vacation rentals in Europe according to the company. As previously outlined, the acquisition could add \(\sim 55\%\) to HomeToGo's IFRS revenue in 2024 on a pro- forma basis while adj. EBITDA would triple. With yesterday's release, HomeToGo is reiterating its current FY25 guidance for the standalone firm and indicates that once the transaction closes, it will review Interhome's financials to provide an updated guidance on the impact to HomeToGo's own financials with the consolidation of the business.

Andre Juillard: Our analysis of STR data for July 2025 reveals a mixed picture for the European hotel sector. While select markets such as Spain (+6.1%), Ireland (+5.5%) and the UK (+3.7%) have demonstrated robust RevPAR growth, driven by a combination of rate and occupancy gains, others, notably the Netherlands (- 8.6%), Germany (- 8.3%) and Belgium (- 5.2%) experienced headwinds last month. However, we expect German RevPAR growth to have normalized after July, once the Euro- 24 comparator has passed. China as expected has continued to decline, with RevPAR of - 3.6%. In the US, overall RevPAR was negative this month at - 1.1%.

Richard Stuber: This is the third of a quarterly periodical where we publish latest trends in the UK holiday market. Our dbDatalnsights team has surveyed 501 individuals in the UK, statistically representative of the UK population. The late booking pattern appears to have played out as expected, with demand remaining strong for packages into the latest market. Whilst there appears to be more sensitivity around price, customers did book and travel this summer. Barclaycard data in July showed spend +2.0%, up from 0.9% in previous months. Our consumer survey data also showed that 91% of customers expected to pay more for this year's summer holiday than last year (+2ppt vs. in 2Q) with noticeable growth in those spending "a lot more", which may reflect the widening financial situations of differing income quintiles (ASDA income tracker). Price inflation for package holidays is also evident in recent CPI data (July +5.7%).

Maria Contreras: The first piece of inflation data for August will come from Belgium on Thursday (28 Aug). Data for the big4 will be released on Friday (29 Aug) while the euro area aggregate print will be out next Tuesday (2 Sep). Our models point to a marginal increase in headline HICP this month to 2.1% YoY (2.0% prev.). This is broadly in line with current market pricing. Energy base effects are behind the projected increase. We expect core HICP to slip to 2.2% YoY (2.3% prev.), driven by easing inflation across both services and core goods. Across countries, we expect inflation to move slightly higher in five of the six major economies.
FOCUS GERMANY - The Future of New Construction II Structural breaks. Consolidation. Boom.

FOCUS GERMANY - The Future of New Construction II Structural breaks. Consolidation. Boom.Jochen Moebert: Consolidation in building construction is progressing rapidly. We expect the trend towards larger and more productive companies with better- paid employees to continue. We also anticipate a further increase in the proportion of companies acting as developers, while the proportion of private households decreases. We maintain our assessment from previous years that even fewer detached houses will be built in the future. The trend towards larger buildings with smaller apartments is likely to persist, primarily due to the housing shortage in metropolitan areas. Prefabricated construction has already gained significant importance in recent years. The high degree of prefabrication offers a clear advantage over conventional, individualized construction. It is likely to enable the rapid integration of new technologies such as digitalization, robotics, and 3D printing. As a result, we expect higher capital intensity and increased productivity. Both of these should contribute to lowering construction costs in the long term.

FX BLOG - On FranceGeorge Saravelos: Newsflow around a potential collapse of the French government has weighed on French bonds and potentially EUR/USD this week. Unless there is a huge shift in the political landscape, we do not see French developments as a sustained driver of the euro for the remainder of the year. First, the market is already pricing a lot of risk premium, as argued by our fixed income colleagues. OATs are now trading cheap on all their valuation metrics and already pricing in rating downgrades (chart 1). Second, despite a very weak government, budget execution this year has been remarkably positive and in line with what would be expected to meet the government's budget deficit target. Third, in the event of the government collapsing, it is not clear to us that the alternative that emerges would be worse than the current status quo. We will get either a new Prime Minister supported by the existing parties, or - in the event of an election - another fragmented parliament.

FX BLOG - Stuck in the middle with youTim Baker: There's a moderately positive USD argument in the market that notes very attractive carry, enduring exceptionalism as evidenced by US equity market strength, and the drop seen already this year. We're not convinced. To be sure, the dollar does in fact look quite low relative to 2- year rate spreads, after following them reasonably closely through much of 2022- 2024. But as we've noted, it overshot plenty around the turn of the year - showing clearly that other factors (ie, geopolitics) can matter. US equities are indeed doing well, but it seems underappreciated that many equity markets around the world are performing similarly well. So that's not really 'US exceptionalism'. In fact, EM equities have fully kept pace with the US equity rally from the April lows.

Chris Robertson: Hold to Buy, Tgt Unch. at USD17. Last Close USD13, Buy. Yesterday, we donned our personal protective equipment and braved the summer heat and sun of Louisiana to attend a guided site visit to the Plaquemines LNG facility with the management team from Venture Global (VG), including CEO Mike Sabel, CFO Jack Thayer, and COO Brian Cothran. We left with a much better understanding of just how complex, disciplined, and deliberate the sequencing of construction activities are to allow for the simultaneous commissioning and construction work that occurs at these projects. While Venture Global is best known for its approach in using factory- built, mid- scale liquefaction trains, we think that this barely scratches the surface of how the Company is differentiating its simultaneous commissioning and construction process.

Henry Allen: Risk assets put in another decent performance yesterday, with the S&P 500 (+0.24%) closing at a new record. But even as US equities reached new heights, there were still plenty of doubts swirling in the background that took some of the shine off that. First were the ongoing questions about the Fed's independence, which led investors to price in faster inflation and drove a fresh round of yield curve steepening. Second, French bonds remained under pressure given the fiscal trajectory there, with the Franco- German 10yr spread up to a 7- month high of 82bps. And after the US close, Nvidia's share price fell in after- hours trading, as their results added to the sense that the explosive growth seen during the AI boom of 2023- 24 was decelerating. So US equity futures have also fallen a bit this morning, with those on the S&P 500 down - 0.12%.

The Equity Rating Dispersion Chart depicts the following:

The proportion of recommendations that are rated "buy", "sell" and "hold" over the previous 12 months. This is shown for securities issued in the stated region e.g. "Europe Universe". See rating definitions below. This is represented by the "Companies Covered" bars in the chart. The percentage value displayed above the bar is the proportion as a percentage. E.g. \(50\%\) above the "buy" / "Companies Covered" bar means that \(50\%\) of DB's equity research covered companies over the past 12 months have a "buy" rating.
Next to each of the three respective bars showing the proportion of "buy", "sell" and "hold" recommendations we provide two additional bars to show:

- The proportion of "buy", "sell" or "hold recommendations where Deutsche Bank and or/Affiliates provided MIFID Investment or Ancillary Services in the past 12 months. This is represented in the "MIFID Investment and Ancillary Services" bar. The percentage value displayed above the bar shows the proportion of Companies Covered with the given rating where DB has also provided MIFID Investment and Ancillary Services in the past 12 months. E.g. \(50\%\) above the "Cos. w/ MIFID Investment and Ancillary Services" bar means \(50\%\) of the Companies Covered with the rating stated have also received MIFID Investment and Ancillary Services from DB.

- The proportion of "buy" (or "sell" or "hold) recommendations where Deutsche Bank and or/Affiliates has provided Investment Banking services in the past 12 months for which it has received compensation. The percentage value displayed above the bar shows the proportion of Companies Covered with the stated rating where DB has also provided Investment Banking services in the past 12 months. E.g. \(50\%\) above the "Cos. w/ Investment Banking relationship" bar means \(50\%\) of the Companies Covered with the rating stated also have an Investment Banking Relationship with DB.
Buy: Based on a current 12- month view of TSR, we recommend that investors buy the stock.
Sell: Based on a current 12- month view of TSR, we recommend that investors sell the stock.
Hold: We take a neutral view on the stock 12- months out and, based on this time horizon, do not recommend either a Buy or Sell.
\(\mathsf{TSR} =\) Total Shareholder Return. Percentage change in share price from current price to projected target price plus projected dividend yield

Macroeconomic fluctuations often account for most of the risks associated with exposures to instruments that promise to pay fixed or variable interest rates. For an investor who is long fixed- rate instruments (thus receiving these cash flows), increases in interest rates naturally lift the discount factors applied to the expected cash flows and thus cause a loss. The longer the maturity of a certain cash flow and the higher the move in the discount factor, the higher will be the loss. Upside surprises in inflation, fiscal funding needs, and FX depreciation rates are among the most common adverse macroeconomic shocks to receivers. But counterparty exposure, issuer creditworthiness, client segmentation, regulation (including changes in assets holding limits for different types of investors), changes in tax policies, currency convertibility (which may constrain currency conversion, repatriation of profits and/or liquidation of positions), and settlement issues related to local clearing houses are also important risk factors. The sensitivity of fixed- income instruments to macroeconomic shocks may be mitigated by indexing the contracted cash flows to inflation, to FX depreciation, or to specified interest rates - these are common in emerging markets. The index fixings may - by construction - lag or mis- measure the actual move in the underlying variables they are intended to track. The choice of the proper fixing (or metric) is particularly important in swaps markets, where floating coupon rates (i.e., coupons indexed to a typically short- dated interest rate reference index) are exchanged for fixed coupons. Funding in a currency that differs from the currency in which coupons are denominated carries FX risk. Options on swaps (swaptions) the risks typical to options in addition to the risks related to rates movements.

Backtested, hypothetical or simulated performance results have inherent limitations. Unlike an actual performance record based on trading actual client portfolios, simulated results are achieved by means of the retroactive application of a backtested model itself designed with the benefit of hindsight. Taking into account historical events the backtesting of performance also differs from actual account performance because an actual investment strategy may be adjusted any time, for any reason, including a response to material, economic or market factors. The backtested performance includes hypothetical results that do not reflect the reinvestment of dividends and other earnings or the deduction of advisory fees, brokerage or other commissions, and any other expenses that a client would have paid or actually paid. No representation is made that any trading strategy or account will or is likely to achieve profits or losses similar to those shown. Alternative modeling techniques or assumptions might produce significantly different results and prove to be more appropriate. Past hypothetical backtest results are neither an indicator nor guarantee of future returns. Actual results will vary, perhaps materially, from the analysis.

The method for computing individual E,S,G and composite ESG scores set forth herein is a novel method developed by the Research department within Deutsche Bank AG, computed using a systematic approach without human intervention. Different data providers, market sectors and geographies approach ESG analysis and incorporate the findings in a variety of ways. As such, the ESG scores referred to herein may differ from equivalent ratings developed and implemented by other ESG data providers in the market and may also differ from equivalent ratings developed and implemented by other divisions within the Deutsche Bank Group. Such ESG scores also differ from other ratings and rankings that have historically been applied in research reports published by Deutsche Bank AG. Further, such ESG scores do not represent a formal or official view of Deutsche Bank AG. It should be noted that the decision to incorporate ESG factors into any investment strategy may inhibit the ability to participate in certain investment opportunities that otherwise would be consistent with your investment objective and other principal investment strategies. The returns on a portfolio consisting primarily of sustainable investments may be lower or higher than portfolios where ESG factors, exclusions, or other sustainability issues are not considered, and the investment opportunities available to such portfolios may differ. Companies may not necessarily meet high performance standards on all aspects of ESG or sustainable investing issues; there is also no guarantee that any company will meet expectations in connection with corporate responsibility, sustainability, and/or impact performance.
